[[Universidad Camilo José Cela|Camilo José Cela University]] (PhD) | signature = Firma Pedro Sánchez.png }} '''Pedro Sánchez Pérez-Castejón''' ({{IPA-es|ˈpeðɾo ˈsantʃeθ ˈpeɾeθ kasteˈxon|lang}}; born 29 February 1972) is a Spanish politician who has been [[Prime Minister of Spain]] since June 2018.{{cite web|website=lamoncloa.gob.es|language=es|title=Relación cronológica de los presidentes del Consejo de Ministros y del Gobierno |url=http://www.lamoncloa.gob.es/presidente/presidentes-desde-1823/Paginas/index.aspx |access-date=5 June 2018}}{{Cite journal|publisher=Agencia Estatal Boletín Oficial del Estado|journal=Boletín Oficial del Estado |issue=134 |date=2 June 2018|language=es|title=Real Decreto 354/2018, de 1 de junio, por el que se nombra Presidente del Gobierno a don Pedro Sánchez Pérez-Castejón|url=https://www.boe.es/boe/dias/2018/06/02/pdfs/BOE-A-2018-7400.pdf|issn=0212-033X|page=57657}} He has also been Secretary-General of the [[Spanish Socialist Workers' Party]] (PSOE) since June 2017, having previously held that office from 2014 to 2016. Sánchez began his political career in 2004 as a city councillor in [[Madrid]], before being elected to the [[Congress of Deputies]] in 2009. In 2014 he was elected Secretary-General of the PSOE, becoming [[Leader of the Opposition (Spain)|Leader of the Opposition]]. He led the party through the inconclusive [[2015 Spanish general election|2015]] and [[2016 Spanish general election|2016 general elections]], but resigned as Secretary-General shortly after the latter, following [[2016 PSOE crisis|public disagreements with the party's executive]]. He was subsequently re-elected in a [[2017 Spanish Socialist Workers' Party leadership election|leadership election]] eight months later, defeating [[Susana Díaz]] and [[Patxi López]]. On 1 June 2018, the PSOE called a [[2018 vote of no confidence in the government of Mariano Rajoy|vote of no confidence]] in Prime Minister [[Mariano Rajoy]], successfully passing the motion after winning the support of [[Unidas Podemos]], as well as various regionalist and nationalist parties. Sánchez was subsequently sworn in as Prime Minister by [[Felipe VI of Spain|King Felipe VI]] the following day. He went on to lead the PSOE to gain 38 seats in the [[April 2019 Spanish general election|April 2019 general election]], the PSOE's first national victory since [[2008 Spanish general election|2008]], although they fell short of a majority. After talks to form a government failed, Sánchez again won the most votes at the [[November 2019 Spanish general election|November 2019 general election]], and in January 2020 he formed a minority [[Sánchez II Government|coalition government]] with [[Unidas Podemos]], the first national coalition government since the country's return to democracy. == Early life == Pedro Sánchez Pérez-Castejón was born in 1972 in [[Madrid]] to a well-off family,{{Cite web|url=https://www.revistavanityfair.es/poder/articulos/pedro-sanchez-padre-madre-hermano-quien-es-mujer-begona-gomez-hijas/43121|website=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|title=Así es la familia más cercana de Pedro Sánchez|first=Nuria|last=Hernández|date=22 March 2020}}[http://www.vanitatis.elconfidencial.com/noticias/2014-06-23/pedro-sanchez-la-vida-familiar-del-politico-al-que-han-apodado-mister-psoe-2014_147991/ Pedro Sánchez, la vida familiar del político al que han apodado 'míster PSOE 2014'] Published by Vanitatis, 23 June 2014, accessed 26 June 2014 son to Pedro Sánchez Fernández and Magdalena Pérez-Castejón. His father was a public administrator long employed at the Ministry of Culture's Instituto Nacional de las Artes Escénicas y de la Música ({{Literal translation|National Institute of the Performing Arts and Music}}). He later became the owner of an industrial packing company. His mother worked as a civil servant in the [[social security in Spain|social security]] system (later becoming a lawyer, graduating with her son at the same university).{{Cite web|url=https://www.revistavanityfair.es/poder/articulos/pedro-sanchez-instituto-ramiro-de-maeztu-colegio-santa-cristina-infancia-estudiantes/33526|website=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|title=¿Por qué Pedro Sánchez jamás habla de su colegio pero siempre presume de instituto?|first=Raquel|last=Peláez|date=10 September 2018}} Raised in the [[Tetuán (Madrid)|Tetuán]] district,{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.es/2016/03/03/cosas-pedro-sanchez_n_9377372.html|website=[[The Huffington Post]]|title=34 cosas que no sabías de Pedro Sánchez|first=Antonio|last=Ruiz Valdivia|date=3 March 2016}} he studied at the Colegio Santa Cristina, also located in the district.{{Cite web|url=https://www.vanitatis.elconfidencial.com/famosos/2019-11-10/ninos-candidatos-presidencia-moncloa-noviembre_1945302/|via=[[El Confidencial]]|website=Vanitatis|title=Así eran de niños los candidatos a Moncloa: baloncesto, guitarra, natación, Maquiavelo...|date=10 November 2019|first=Silvia|last=Taulés}} According to Sánchez himself, he frequented [[breakdancing]] circles in [[AZCA]] when he was a teenager.{{Cite web|date=26 November 2015|title=El joven Pedro Sánchez, bailarín de 'break dance', "ligón" y "un poco bala"|url=https://www.mediaset.es/telemania/gente-de-tele/bertin-osborne-entrevista-pedro-sanchez-tuya-mia-tve_0_2090025055.html|publisher=[[Mediaset]]}}{{Cite web|website=Somos Tetuán|via=[[eldiario.es]]|title=Los chavales de AZCA: cómo el distrito financiero de Madrid fue colonizado por la cultura urbana|first=Luis de la|last=Cruz|date=6 December 2020|url=https://www.eldiario.es/madrid/somos/tetuan/historia/chavales-azca-distrito-financiero-madrid-colonizado-cultura-urbana_1_6485316.html}} He moved from the Colegio Santa Cristina to the Instituto Ramiro de Maeztu, a public high school where he played basketball in the [[CB Estudiantes|Estudiantes]] [[cantera|youth system]], with links to the high school, reaching the U-21 team.{{cite web |url=http://www.psoe.es/conocenos/secretaria-general/ |title=Pedro Sánchez, Secretaría general |language=es |trans-title=Pedro Sánchez, Secretary-General |work=PSOE |access-date=27 December 2015 }} In 1990, Sánchez went to study economics and business sciences. In 1993, he joined the PSOE after the victory of [[Felipe González]] in the [[1993 Spanish general election|elections that year]].{{cite news|url=http://politica.elpais.com/politica/2014/06/12/actualidad/1402576371_029298.html |title=Una carrera guiada por el azar |author=Fernando Garea |language=es |work=[[El País]] |date=12 July 2014|access-date=27 July 2014}} Sánchez earned a [[licentiate degree]] from the [[Real Centro Universitario Escorial-Maria Christina|Real Colegio Universitario María Cristina]], attached to the [[Complutense University of Madrid]], in 1995.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cope.es/actualidad/espana/noticias/curriculum-pedro-sanchez-una-tesis-tres-masteres-20180914_258513|website=[[Cadena COPE|COPE]]|title=El currículum de Pedro Sánchez: una tesis... ¿y tres másteres?|date=14 September 2018}} Following his graduation he worked in [[New York City|New York]] for a consulting firm.{{Cite web|url=https://www.elmundo.es/cronica/2016/02/28/56d175d9268e3e7b348b4685.html|website=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]|title=Cuando Pedro Sánchez 'negoció' con un criminal de guerra|first=Leyre|last=Iglesias|date=28 February 2016}} In 1998, before entering a career in local and national politics, Sánchez started to work in [[Brussels]] in the PSOE's delegation to the [[European Parliament]] as assistant to MEP [[Bárbara Dührkop]].{{Cite web|website=La Nueva España|title=Diez cosas que quizá desconoces de Pedro Sánchez|date=21 June 2015|url=https://www.lne.es/espana/2015/06/21/diez-cosas-desconoces-pedro-sanchez-19664763.html}} He also worked in the staff of the [[United Nations]] high representative in Bosnia, [[Carlos Westendorp]].{{Cite news|url=https://elpais.com/politica/2018/06/09/actualidad/1528566923_692000.html|website=[[El País]]|title=Los padrinos del presidente|date=11 June 2019|first=Jordi|last=Pérez Colomé}} He earned a degree in Politics and Economics in 1998 after graduating from the [[Université libre de Bruxelles]].{{citation needed|date=December 2020}} He earned a degree of business leadership from [[IESE Business School]] in the [[University of Navarra]], a private university and apostolate of the [[Opus Dei]].{{failed verification|date=December 2020}}{{cite news|url=http://politica.elpais.com/politica/2015/11/19/actualidad/1447947868_898425.html|title=¿Qué carrera tiene Pedro Sánchez?|work=[[El País]]|date=19 November 2015|language=es|access-date=6 September 2016 }} Sánchez obtained a diploma in Advanced Studies in EU Monetary Integration from the Instituto Ortega y Gasset in 2002. == Political career == === Early local and national career === In 2003, Sánchez stood in the [[Madrid City Council]] election on the PSOE list headed by [[Trinidad Jiménez]]. He was 23rd on the proportional representation list, but the PSOE only won 21 seats. Sánchez did not become a city councillor until a year later, when two socialist councillors resigned. He quickly became one of the fundamental components of opposition leader Trinidad Jiménez's team. Between 18 May 2004 – 15 September 2009, he was one of the 57 members of the [[City Council of Madrid]], representing [[PSOE]] in the city of Madrid. At the same time, he went to help the [[PSdG]] (PSOE's affiliated party in Galicia) contest the [[2005 Galician parliamentary election|2005 Galician regional election]], in which PSdG won eight seats, allowing [[Emilio Pérez Touriño]] to become president of Galicia. In 2007, he was part of the Miguel Sebastián campaign for Madrid's premiership. In parallel to his seat at the city council, Sánchez started to work as instructor at the [[Universidad Camilo José Cela]] (UCJC) in 2008, lecturing about Economic Structure and History of Economic Thought. [[File:Candidatura de Madrid PSOE 2011.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.70|Sánchez in the PSOE campaign for the 2011 general election]] Sánchez was elected to the [[Congress of Deputies (Spain)|Congress of Deputies]] for [[Madrid (Congress of Deputies constituency)|Madrid]], replacing [[Pedro Solbes]], Minister of Economy and Finance in the [[José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero]] cabinet, after Solbes retired from politics in 2009. In the [[2011 Spanish general election|general election of 2011]], which saw a heavy defeat for the Socialists, PSOE placed Sánchez 11th on the Proportional Representation list, while only electing 10 deputies. Having thus failed to win a seat, he focused on preparing his [[Doctorate]] in Economics at the UCJC, earning the PhD in November 2012 by writing a dissertation titled ''Innovaciones de la diplomacia económica española: Análisis del sector público (2000–2012)'' (English translation: Innovations of Spanish Economic Diplomacy: Analysis of the Public Sector (2000–2012)) supervised by María Isabel Cepeda González.{{Cite journal|first=Sebastiaan|last=Faber|title=Pedro Sánchez: la construcción de un candidato a través de su tesis doctoral|date=14 December 2015|website=[[La Marea]]|url=https://www.lamarea.com/2015/12/14/pedro-sanchez-la-construccion-de-un-candidato-a-traves-de-su-tesis-doctoral/}} In 2018 Sánchez was accused by the Spanish daily [[ABC (newspaper)|''ABC'']] of plagiarism.{{cite web|last=Chicote |first=Javier |title=Sánchez plagió en su libro 161 líneas con 1.651 palabras de seis textos ajenos y sin ningún tipo de cita |url=https://www.abc.es/espana/abci-sanchez-plagio-libro-161-lineas-1651-palabras-seis-textos-ajenos-y-sin-ningun-tipo-cita-201809232157_noticia.html |work=ABC |date=24 September 2018 |access-date=28 February 2019|language=es}} In order to refute the plagiarism allegations, Sánchez published his full thesis online.{{cite web |last1=Tamma |first1=Paola |title=Pedro Sánchez publishes PhD thesis to rebut plagiarism claims |url=https://www.politico.eu/article/pedro-sanchez-publishes-phd-thesis-to-rebut-plagiarism-claims/ |website=Politico |date=15 September 2018 |access-date=14 September 2021}}{{cite web |last1=Sánchez Pérez-Castejón |first1=Pedro |title=INNOVACIONES DE LA DIPLOMACIA ECONÓMICA ESPAÑOLA: ANÁLISIS DEL SECTOR PÚBLICO (2000–2012) |url=https://ep00.epimg.net/descargables/2018/09/14/e3b8d406f123555d76b8e919686d4878.pdf |access-date=14 September 2021}} In January 2013, Sánchez returned to Congress, replacing [[Cristina Narbona]], who left her seat to enter the [[Nuclear Safety Council (Spain)|Nuclear Safety Council]]. In December 2013, after numerous Socialist leaders such as [[Elena Valenciano]], [[Trinidad Jiménez]], [[Miguel Sebastián]], and [[José Blanco López]] attended his new book release, his name began to be discussed as a prospective candidate for the party leadership. Sánchez officially launched his bid to party leader on 12 June 2014. He was elected as the Secretary-General on 13 July, after winning 49% of votes against his opponents [[Eduardo Madina]] and [[José Antonio Pérez Tapias]] (member of the Socialist Left platform).{{cite web |url=http://www.thespainreport.com/9777/pedro-sanchez-voted-new-secretary-general-spanish-socialist-party-xx-vote/ |title=Pedro Sánchez Voted New Secretary General of Spanish Socialist Party (PSOE) with 49% of Vote | the Spain Report |access-date=25 September 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141016191139/https://www.thespainreport.com/9777/pedro-sanchez-voted-new-secretary-general-spanish-socialist-party-xx-vote/ |archive-date=16 October 2014 }} He was confirmed as Secretary-General after an Extraordinary Congress of the PSOE was held on 26–27 July that ratified the electoral result. === Leading the opposition === Representing a platform based on political regeneration, Sánchez demanded constitutional reforms establishing [[federalism]] as the form of administrative organization of Spain to ensure that Catalonia would remain within the country; a new progressive fiscal policy; extending the welfare state to all citizens; joining [[labour union]]s again to strengthen economic recovery; and regaining the confidence of former Socialist voters disenchanted by the measures taken by Zapatero during his term as Prime Minister amid an economic crisis. He also opposed the [[grand coalition]] model supported by the former Prime Minister and PSOE leader [[Felipe González]], who lobbied in favour of the German system in case of political instability. Sánchez asked his European party caucus not to vote for the consensus candidate [[Jean-Claude Juncker]] of the [[European People's Party]].{{cite web |url=http://www.euractiv.com/sections/eu-elections-2014/spanish-socialists-vote-against-juncker-canete-308462 |title=Spanish socialists to vote against Juncker, Cañete |last=Gotev |first=Georgi |date=16 September 2014 |access-date=8 January 2015 |work=[[Euractiv]]}} Upon taking office as PSOE's Secretary-General, Sánchez faced a political crisis after the formation of a new party, [[Podemos (Spanish political party)|Podemos]]. Approximately 25% of all PSOE supporters switched their loyalties to Podemos.{{cite news |url=http://www.europapress.es/nacional/noticia-45-votantes-iu-icv-2011-28-upyd-24-psoe-apuestan-ahora-podemos-20141105193223.html |title=¿De dónde vienen los votos de Podemos? |language=es |trans-title=Where do the votes of Podemos come from? |work=europa press |date=5 November 2014 |access-date=29 December 2015 }}{{cite news |last=Díez |first=Anabel |url=http://politica.elpais.com/politica/2015/07/26/actualidad/1437937474_105154.html |title=Pedro Sánchez, en proceso |language=es |trans-title=Pedro Sánchez, in process |work=El Pais |date=6 July 2015 |access-date=29 December 2015 }} Sánchez's political agenda included reforming the constitution, establishing a federal model in Spain to replace the current devolution model,{{cite news |last=Díez |first=Anabel |url=http://politica.elpais.com/politica/2014/11/09/actualidad/1415546589_008826.html |title=Ni fractura, ni independencia, una España federal para todos |language=es |trans-title=No fracture, no independence, a federal Spain for all |work=El Pais |date=9 November 2014 |access-date=29 December 2015 }} and further secularization of Spain's education system, including the removal of religion-affiliated public and private schools.{{cite news |last=SANZ |first=LUIS ÁNGEL |url=http://www.elmundo.es/espana/2015/10/19/5625237d46163f09298b460f.html |title=El PSOE eliminará la religión en colegios públicos y privados |language=es |trans-title=The PSOE to eliminate religion in all public and private schools |work=El Mundo(ES) |date=19 October 2015 |access-date=29 December 2015 }} He named [[César Luena]] as his second-in-command. On 21 June 2015, Sánchez was officially announced as the PSOE premiership candidate for the December 2015 general election. His party earned 90 seats, being second to rivals of Partido Popular (PP), who won the election with 123 representatives out of a parliament formed by 350. Since PP's leader did not stand officially for the premiership, following this Sánchez was requested by the King to form a coalition, but he was unable to obtain the support of a majority of representatives. This led to a further [[Spanish general election|general election in June 2016]], where he stood again as PSOE's prospective candidate to prime minister. The party won only 85 seats in the general election. === Removal and political comeback === Amid deep inner strife within the party started by September 2016 (the [[2016 PSOE crisis]]), Sánchez lost support from the PSOE's federal committee in a key vote and was forced to resign as Secretary-General on 1 October 2016.{{Cite web|url=https://www.rtve.es/noticias/20161001/sanchez-dimite-tras-ser-derrotado-criticos-perder-votacion-sobre-primarias-congreso-expres/1417684.shtml|publisher=[[RTVE]]|title=Sánchez dimite tras ser derrotado por sus críticos y perder la votación sobre primarias y el Congreso 'exprés'|date=1 October 2016}} His defeated proposal (107 in favour versus 132 against) was that of celebrate a snap PSOE primary election in October 2016 and a party congress in November. {{Multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | image1 = Pedro-Sanchez-primarias-PSOE-Internacional EDIIMA20170522 0010 19.jpg | caption1 = Pedro Sánchez, after winning the primary election for Secretary-General, singing ''[[The Internationale]]''. | image2 = Mariano Rajoy felicita al nuevo presidente del Gobierno Pedro Sánchez (2018-06-01).jpg | caption2 = Rajoy congratulates Sánchez on his successful no-confidence motion. }} In order to avoid obeying the directive of the PSOE's interim leadership to facilitate Mariano Rajoy's investiture as Prime Minister by means of an abstention and thus "betraying his word", Sánchez also renounced to his seat at the Congress of Deputies in October 2016, and started to prepare for a new candidacy to the leadership of the party in the upcoming primary election.{{Cite news|url=https://elpais.com/politica/2016/10/29/actualidad/1477735635_217414.html|website=[[El País]]|date=29 October 2016|title=Pedro Sánchez deja el escaño y lanza su candidatura a la secretaría general|first1=Anabel|last1=Díez|first2=José|last2=Marcos}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.economiahoy.mx/internacional-eAm-mexico/noticias/9179030/06/18/Pedro-Sanchez-el-madrileno-que-no-conseguia-ser-diputado-y-acabo-como-presidente-de-Espana.html|website=Economiahoy.mx|date=1 June 2018|title=Pedro Sánchez, el madrileño que no conseguía ser diputado y acabó como presidente de España|first=Víctor|last=Ventura}} Besides the renunciation of Sánchez, 15 PSOE MPs would break party discipline by voting against Rajoy,{{refn|group=n.|[[Meritxell Batet]], Marc Lamuà, [[Manuel Cruz Rodríguez|Manuel Cruz]], María Mercè Perea, Lídia Guinart, Joan Ruiz, José Zaragoza, [[Margarita Robles]], [[Zaida Cantera]], Odón Elorza, Pere Joan Pons, Sofía Hernanz, María del Rocío de Frutos, [[Susana Sumelzo]] and María Luz Martínez.}} yet as Rajoy only needed the abstention from 11 PSOE MPs (out of 84), the latter was invested as Prime Minister.{{Cite news|url=https://elpais.com/politica/2016/10/29/actualidad/1477739886_198194.html|website=[[El País]]|title=Los 15 diputados del PSOE que votaron no|first1=Anabel|last1=Díez|first2=José|last2=Marcos|date=30 October 2016 }} After resigning as Secretary-General of the party and to prepare for his bid to party leadership, Sánchez made a tour aboard his car visiting base members in different parts of Spain.{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/887cedda-699d-11e8-b6eb-4acfcfb08c11|work=[[Financial Times]]|title=Pedro Sánchez, a dogged politician who grabbed his chance|first1=Michael|last1=Stothard|date=8 June 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.eleconomista.es/politica/noticias/9179988/06/18/Sanchez-el-politico-de-las-siete-vidas.html|newspaper=El Economista|language=es|last1=Zancajo|date=3 June 2018|title=Pedro Sánchez, el político de las siete vidas|trans-title=Pedro Sánchez, the politician of the seven lives|first1=Silvia}} On 21 May 2017, Sánchez was re-elected Secretary-General for the second time with 50.2% of the votes, over his competitors [[Susana Díaz]] (39.94%) and [[Patxi López]] (9.85%).[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/may/21/spanish-socialists-re-elect-pedro-sanchez-to-lead-party Spanish Socialists re-elect Pedro Sánchez to lead party] TheGuardian.com Sánchez opposed the [[2017 Catalan independence referendum|Catalan independence referendum]] and supported the [[Mariano Rajoy|Rajoy]] government's decision to dismiss the [[Generalitat de Catalunya|Catalan government]] and impose direct rule on [[Catalonia]] in October 2017.{{cite news |title=Spain's Pedro Sánchez forced to confront Catalonia crisis |url=https://www.ft.com/content/36229ab2-670e-11e8-b6eb-4acfcfb08c11 |newspaper=[[Financial Times]] |date=4 June 2018 |access-date=3 September 2018 |first=Michael |last=Stothard |agency=Nikkei Company}}{{cite news |title=Catalan nationalists back in power, target secession in challenge to Sanchez |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-spain-politics-catalonia/nationalists-back-in-power-in-catalonia-say-target-independence-idUSKCN1IY0B8 |work=[[Reuters]] |date=2 June 2018 |access-date=3 September 2018 |first1=Jesús |last1=Aguado |first2=Ingrid |last2=Melander}} {{See also|2018 vote of no confidence in the government of Mariano Rajoy}} In May 2018, after verdicts were announced in the [[Gurtel case|Gürtel trial]], PSOE filed a successful no-confidence motion against Mariano Rajoy.{{Cite news |url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2018/05/25/inenglish/1527237249_668560.html |title=Socialist party chief calls for transitional government |last=Garcia |first=Elsa |date=25 April 2018 |access-date=1 June 2018 |newspaper=[[El País]] |location=Madrid}} Per the Constitution, Spanish votes of no confidence are [[constructive vote of no confidence|constructive]]; those bringing the motion must propose a replacement candidate for Prime Minister. Accordingly, the PSOE proposed Sánchez (who was not a member of the Congress of Deputies at the time) as Rajoy's replacement. With the passage of the no-confidence motion, Sánchez was automatically deemed to have the confidence of the Congress of Deputies and thus ascended as Prime Minister on 1 June 2018. == Premiership (2018–present) == {{Main|Premiership of Pedro Sánchez}} {{See also|Sánchez I Government|Sánchez II Government}} [[File:Primer Gobierno de Pedro Sánchez (2018-06).jpg|thumb|Sánchez and his new cabinet at [[La Moncloa]] in June 2018]] Sánchez was sworn in as Prime Minister by King Felipe VI on 2 June.{{cite news |title=Who is Spain's new President of the Government, Pedro Sanchez? |url=http://www.dw.com/en/who-is-spains-new-prime-minister-pedro-sanchez/a-44041431 |access-date=1 June 2018 |work=Reuters, AFP |publisher=DW |date=1 June 2018}} Sánchez said he planned to form a government that would eventually dissolve the [[Cortes Generales]] and call for a general election, but he did not specify when he would do it while also saying that before calling for an election he intended take a series of measures like increasing unemployment benefits and proposing a law of equal pay between the sexes.{{cite news|last=Ruiz de Almirón|first=Victor|date=1 June 2018|title=Sánchez llega al poder sin concretar cuándo convocará las elecciones|language=es|newspaper=[[ABC (Spain)|ABC]]|url=http://www.abc.es/espana/abci-sanchez-llega-poder-sin-concretar-cuando-convocara-elecciones-201806010320_noticia.html|access-date=9 July 2018}}{{cite news |url=http://www.eleconomista.es/economia/noticias/9179627/06/18/Sanchez-prioriza-la-agenda-social-y-renuncia-a-realizar-reformas-en-profundidad.html |title=Sánchez prioriza la agenda social y renuncia a realizar reformas en profundidad |last=Zancajo |first=Silvia |date=1 June 2018 |access-date=9 July 2018 |newspaper=[[El Economista (Spain)|El Economista]] |language=es |publisher=Editorial Ecoprensa, [[Sociedad Anónima|S.A.]]}} However, he also said he would uphold the 2018 budget approved by the Rajoy government, a condition the [[Basque Nationalist Party]] imposed to vote for the motion of no-confidence.{{cite news |url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/politica/20180531/443963185308/pedro-sanchez-rajoy-dimita-mocion-de-censura.html |title=Sánchez ofrece diálogo a Catalunya y mantener los presupuestos al PNV |last=Merino |first=Juan Carlos |date=31 May 2018 |access-date=9 July 2018 |newspaper=[[La Vanguardia]] |language=es}} Spanish media noted that while Sánchez was swearing his oath of office on the [[Spanish Constitution]], no [[Bible]] or [[crucifix]] were on display for the first time in modern Spanish history, due to Sánchez's atheism.{{cite news |url=https://www.eldiario.es/politica/Pedro-Sanchez-presidente-presencia-Rajoy_0_777972264.html |title=Pedro Sánchez promete su cargo de presidente ante el rey y Rajoy, sin crucifijo ni Biblia |last=Aduriz |first=Íñigo |date=2 June 2018 |access-date=9 July 2018 |newspaper=[[El Diario (Spain)|El Diario]] |language=es}} After being sworn in, Sánchez announced that he would only propose measures that had considerable parliamentary support, and re-affirmed the government's compliance with the EU deficit requirements.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jun/06/new-spanish-pm-appoints-astronaut-pedro-duque-science-minister|title=Spanish PM appoints 11 women and six men to new cabinet|last=Jones|first=Sam|date=6 June 2018|work=The Guardian|access-date=20 March 2019|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} === Foreign policy === [[File:Pedro Sánchez conferencia "Proteger el ideal de Europa" 02.jpg|thumb|Sánchez during his speech at the event organized by the Spanish Federal Council of the European Movement on 19 March 2019.]] Sánchez has taken a more active role in the international sphere, especially in the European Union, saying that "Spain has to claim its role" and declaring himself "a militant pro-European".{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.eu/article/pedro-sanchez-sets-sights-on-brussels-spain-eu/|title=Pedro Sánchez sets sights on Brussels|date=21 November 2018|website=POLITICO|access-date=20 March 2019}} On 16 January 2019, in a speech before the [[European Parliament]], he said that the EU should be protected and turned into a global actor, and that a more social Europe is needed, with a strong monetary union.{{cite web|url=https://www.euractiv.com/section/eu-elections-2019/news/spanish-pm-if-europe-is-to-protect-us-we-need-to-protect-europe/|title=Spanish PM: If Europe protects us, we need to protect Europe|last=Rios|first=Beatriz|date=17 January 2019|website=euractiv.com|language=en-GB|access-date=20 March 2019}} He stated in a speech in March 2019 adding that the enemies of Europe are inside of the European Union.{{cite web|url=https://www.eldiario.es/politica/Sanchez-advierte-enemigos-Europa-fuerzas_0_879462938.html|title=Sánchez advierte de que los "enemigos" de Europa están "dentro" y llama a votar contra las fuerzas "unidas por sus odios"|last=Castro|first=Irene|website=eldiario.es|date=19 March 2019 |language=es|access-date=20 March 2019}}{{Cite web|last=Welle (www.dw.com)|first=Deutsche|title=EU nominations 2019: Who is Spain's Josep Borrell? {{!}} DW {{!}} 03.07.2019|url=https://www.dw.com/en/eu-nominations-2019-who-is-spains-josep-borrell/a-49453057|access-date=2020-06-25|website=DW.COM|language=en-GB}} In [[Sánchez II Government|his second government]], he continued strengthening the pro-European profile of its ministers, appointing [[José Luis Escrivá]], the then chair of the [[Independent Authority for Fiscal Responsibility]] and former chair of the [[EU Independent Fiscal Institutions Network]], as minister for social security.{{Cite web|date=2020-01-10|title=José Luis Escrivá, new Minister of Social Security, Inclusion and Migration|url=https://www.eldiario.es/economia/Escriva-ministro-Seguridad-Inclusion-Migraciones_0_983052315.html|access-date=2020-06-25|website=Spain's News|language=en-US}} In June 2020, the Sánchez government proposed deputy prime minister and economy minister, [[Nadia Calviño]], to be the next chair of the [[Eurogroup]].{{Cite news|date=2020-06-25|title=Spain to propose Economy Minister Calvino as Eurogroup chief|language=en|work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-spain-eu-calvino-idUSKBN23W0QD|access-date=2020-06-25}} Following the [[Fall of Kabul (2021)|fall of Kabul]] and the subsequent ''de facto'' creation of the [[Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan]], the Prime Minister offered Spain as a hub for Afghans who collaborated with the European Union, which would later be settled in various countries.{{Cite web|date=2021-08-20|title=Spain offers itself as hub for Afghans who collaborated with EU|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/aug/20/spain-offers-itself-as-hub-for-eus-afghans|access-date=2021-08-22|website=the Guardian|language=en}} The Spanish government created a temporary refugee camp in the air base of [[Madrid–Torrejón Airport|Torrejón de Ardoz]], which was later visited by officials from the European Union, including [[president of the European Commission]] [[Ursula von der Leyen]] and [[president of the European Council]] [[Charles Michel]]. Von der Leyen praised Sánchez government's initiative, stating that the actions of Spain represents "a good example of the European soul at its best".{{Cite web|last=Rodríguez-Pina|first=Gloria|date=2021-08-21|title=Von der Leyen considera la acogida de afganos en España "un ejemplo del alma europea"|url=https://elpais.com/internacional/2021-08-21/von-der-leyen-considera-la-acogida-de-afganos-en-espana-un-ejemplo-del-alma-europea.html|access-date=2021-08-22|website=EL PAÍS|language=es}} [[President of the United States|US President]] [[Joe Biden]] spoke with Sánchez to allow the use of the military bases of [[Naval Station Rota|Rota]] and [[Morón Air Base|Morón]] to temporarily accommodate Afghan refugees, while praising "Spain's leadership in seeking international support for Afghan women and girls".{{Cite web|date=2021-08-21|title=Readout of President Joe Biden's Call with President Pedro Sánchez of Spain|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/08/21/readout-of-president-joe-bidens-call-with-president-pedro-sanchez-of-spain/|access-date=2021-08-22|website=The White House|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|date=2021-08-21|title=Biden habla con Sánchez tras la afrenta de los agradecimientos por Afganistán|url=https://www.abc.es/espana/abci-sanchez-habla-biden-telefono-sobre-afganistan-202108220010_noticia.html|access-date=2021-08-22|website=abc|language=es}}[[File:2018-06-26, Pedro Sánchez se reúne con Angela Merkel 4.jpg|thumb|Sánchez with German Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]], 26 June 2018]] === Domestic policy === On 18 June 2018, Sánchez' government announced its intention to remove the remains of former dictator [[Francisco Franco]] from the [[Valley of the Fallen]].{{cite news |url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2018/06/18/inenglish/1529307821_499020.html |title=Removal of Franco's remains from Valley of the Fallen one step closer |first=Natalia |last=Junquera |date=18 June 2018 |access-date=3 September 2018 |location=Madrid |language=es |newspaper=[[El País]] |publisher=Prisa}} On 24 August 2018, Sánchez's cabinet approved a decree that modifies two aspects of the 2007 [[Historical Memory Law]] to allow the exhumation of Franco's remains from the Valley of the Fallen. After a year of legal battles with Franco's descendants, the exhumation took place on 24 October 2019, and Franco was reburied at [[Mingorrubio Cemetery]] in [[El Pardo]] with his wife [[Carmen Polo, 1st Lady of Meirás|Carmen Polo]].{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/oct/23/francos-remains-to-finally-leave-spains-valley-of-the-fallen|title=Franco's remains to finally leave Spain's Valley of the Fallen|first=Sam|last=Jones|date=23 October 2019|via=www.theguardian.com}} After the sentence in [[Trial of Catalonia independence leaders|2019 trial of Catalonia independence leaders]] Sánchez confirmed his support of the sentence, and denied the possibility of any indulgence, proclaiming that the sentence should be served by the convicts in its entirety,{{Cite news|date=October 14, 2019|title=Sánchez aleja un indulto y defiende el fallo: "Garantizamos su absoluto cumplimiento"|work=El Pais|url=https://elpais.com/politica/2019/10/14/actualidad/1571041641_229924.html}} in spite of that two years later Sánchez granted indulgence to all convicts.{{Cite news|date=June 30, 2021|title=Sánchez defiende en el Congreso los indultos a los presos del 'procés'|work=El Pais|url=https://elpais.com/espana/2021-06-30/sanchez-defiende-en-el-congreso-los-indultos-a-los-presos-del-proces.html}} Shortly after granting the indulgence, Sánchez stressed that despite the indulgence, there would never be a referendum for the independence of Catalonia,{{Cite news|title=Sánchez: "No habrá referéndum de autodeterminación. Nunca, jamás"|work=El Pais|url=https://elpais.com/espana/2021-06-30/sanchez-no-habra-referendum-de-autodeterminacion-nunca-jamas.html}} in response he was mocked by [[Gabriel Rufián|Gabriel Rufian]] and other Catalan politicians, who reminded him that two years prior he had made the same claim with regards to granting indulgences, and insinuated that it is just a matter of time before Sánchez will break his latest claims. Under Sánchez's leadership, the [[Cortes Generales]] approved a total central government budget of 196 billion euros – the biggest budget in the country's history – in 2021, after he had won the support of the Catalan pro-independence [[Republican Left of Catalonia]].Daniel Dombey (25 November 2021), [https://www.ft.com/content/de8b3f00-03c6-44bb-a947-3a80c1969bfd Spain passes biggest budget in its history] ''[[Financial Times]]''. ==== COVID-19 pandemic ==== {{Main|COVID-19 pandemic in Spain}} [[File:Pedro Sánchez estado de alarma.jpg|thumb|Sánchez announcing the state of alarm on 13 March 2020.]] On 13 March 2020, Sánchez announced a declaration of the [[State of alarm (Spain)|state of alarm]] in the nation for a period of 15 days, to become effective the following day after the approval of the Council of Ministers, becoming the second time in democratic history and the first time with this magnitude.{{cite web|last=Blas|first=Carlos E. Cué, Claudi Pérez, Elsa García de|date=2020-03-13|title=Sánche decreta el estado de alarma durante 15 días|url=https://elpais.com/espana/2020-03-13/el-gobierno-debate-decretar-el-estado-de-alarma.html|access-date=2020-03-13|website=EL PAÍS|language=es}} The following day imposed a [[2020 Spain coronavirus lockdown|nationwide lockdown]], banning all trips that were not force majeure and announced it may intervene in companies to guarantee supplies.{{cite news|last=Health|first=P. M. N.|date=14 March 2020|title=Spain to impose nationwide lockdown – El Mundo | National Post|newspaper=National Post |url=https://nationalpost.com/pmn/health-pmn/spain-to-impose-nationwide-lockdown-el-mundo}}{{cite web|last=Cué|first=Carlos E.|date=2020-03-14|title=El Gobierno prohíbe todos los viajes que no sean de fuerza mayor|url=https://elpais.com/espana/2020-03-14/el-gobierno-prohibe-todos-los-viajes-que-no-sean-de-fuerza-mayor.html|access-date=2020-03-14|website=EL PAÍS|language=es}} On July 14, 2021, the [[Constitutional Court of Spain]], acting upon the 2020'th appeal by [[Vox (political party)|Vox]], sentenced by a narrow majority (6 votes in support ''vs.'' 5 votes against) that the state of alarm was unconstitutional in the part of suppressing the [[freedom of movement]] established by the Article 19 of the [[Constitution of Spain]].{{Cite news|date=July 14, 2021|title=Un Constitucional dividido anula el confinamiento domiciliario impuesto en el primer estado de alarma|work=El Mundo|url=https://www.elmundo.es/espana/2021/07/14/60ed7a8ae4d4d860208b4571.html}} == Ideology == Sánchez ran in the 2014 PSOE primary election under what has been described as a [[centrist]] and [[social liberal]] profile, later switching to the left in his successful 2017 bid to return to the PSOE leadership in which he stood for a refoundation of [[social democracy]], in order to transition to a "post-capitalist society", ending "[[neoliberalism|neoliberal capitalism]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.letraslibres.com/espana-mexico/politica/pedro-sanchez-victoria-en-victoria-hasta-la-derrota|title=Pedro Sánchez: De victoria en victoria hasta la derrota|website=Letras Libres|date=12 November 2019 |language=es|access-date=14 January 2020}}{{cite web|url=https://www.diariosur.es/nacional/201705/22/pedro-sanchez-fenix-camaleonico-20170522011859-v.html|title=Pedro Sánchez, el fénix camaleónico|date=22 May 2017|website=Diario Sur|language=es|access-date=14 January 2020}}{{cite web|url=https://www.eldiario.es/politica/Postcapitalismo-militancia-izquierda-Pedro-Sanchez_0_614539290.html|title=Pedro Sánchez gira a la izquierda y elige al neoliberalismo como gran enemigo del PSOE|website=Eldiario.es|date=20 February 2017 |language=es|access-date=14 January 2020}}{{cite web|url=http://www.letraslibres.com/espana-mexico/politica/el-psoe-y-la-fatiga-democratica|title=El PSOE y la fatiga democrática|website=Letras Libres|date=28 September 2016 |language=es|access-date=14 January 2020}} A key personal idea posed in his 2019 ''Manual de Resistencia'' book is the indissoluble link between "social democracy" and "Europe".{{cite news|url=https://elpais.com/politica/2019/02/20/actualidad/1550693890_133147.html|title=La ideología de Pedro Sánchez|last=Estefanía|first=Joaquín|date=21 February 2019|work=El País|access-date=14 January 2020|language=es|issn=1134-6582}} Sánchez is a strong opponent of prostitution, and supports its abolition.{{Cite web|last=Encarnación|first=Omar G.|title=Why Does Spain's Progressive Prime Minister Want to Ban Prostitution?|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2021/11/08/spain-prostitution-ban-pedro-sanchez-sex-work-feminism-human-rights-psoe-vox/|access-date=2022-01-05|website=Foreign Policy|language=en-US}} == Personal life == Sánchez married María Begoña Gómez Fernández{{Cite web|date=2018-08-14|title=El misterioso currículum de Begoña Gómez: ni rastro de sus publicitadas titulaciones académicas|url=https://www.elespanol.com/espana/20180814/misterioso-curriculum-begona-gomez-publicitadas-titulaciones-academicas/329967846_0.html|access-date=2020-10-06|website=El Español|language=es-ES}} in 2006 and they have two daughters, Ainhoa and Carlota. The civil wedding was officiated by [[Trinidad Jiménez]]. Aside from Spanish, Sánchez speaks fluent English and French.{{cite web |title=A Conversation with Pedro Sánchez |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G-XqGH4atTc |website=YouTube |publisher=Council on Foreign Relations |access-date=25 November 2018}}{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.es/espana/20140531/abci-pedro-sanchez-psoe-desconocido-201405301642.html |title=El ascenso de Pedro Sánchez: de diputado "desconocido" a secretario general del PSOE |language=es |trans-title=The rise of Pedro Sánchez: from "unknown" deputy to general secretary of the PSOE |work=ABC |date=13 July 2014 |access-date=27 December 2015 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/Diputados/BusqForm?_piref73_1333155_73_1333154_1333154.next_page=/wc/fichaDiputado&idDiputado=381|title=X Legislatura (2011-Actualidad)Sánchez Pérez-Castejón, Pedro|author=[[Congress of Deputies (Spain)]]}} He is the first Spanish prime minister fluent in English while in office (former PM [[José María Aznar]] learned English after leaving office). Foreign languages were not widely taught in Spanish schools until the mid-[[1970s]], and former Prime Ministers were known for struggling with them.{{cite web|url=http://revista.muesca.es/documentos/cabas8/La_lengua_inglesa.pdf |title=The teaching of English language in the Spanish education system |publisher=Javier Barbero Andrés, University of Cantabria |access-date=2 June 2020 |language=es}}{{cite web|url=https://www.20minutos.es/noticia/3377317/0/asi-hablaban-ingles-presidentes-gobierno/|title=Así hablaban inglés los presidentes del Gobierno: de los intentos de Aznar al "no, hombre, no" de Rajoy|author=20 Minutos|date=25 June 2018 }} He is an outspoken [[atheism|atheist]].{{cite web|url=http://www.elplural.com/2014/09/25/pedro-sanchez-primer-aspirante-a-la-moncloa-que-se-declara-abiertamente-ateo/ |title=Pedro Sánchez, primer aspirante a La Moncloa que se declara abiertamente "ateo" |publisher=El Plural |date=24 September 2014 |access-date=2 March 2016 |language=es}} == Controversies == === Saudi Arabia === In September 2018, during his first term in office as Prime Minister, Defense Minister [[Margarita Robles]] cancelled sales of [[laser-guided bomb]]s to [[Saudi Arabia]] over concerns relating to the [[Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen]]. Overruling Robles, Sánchez ordered the sale to proceed{{cite news|date=22 October 2018|title=Spain not stopping arms sales to Saudi Arabia over Khashoggi killing|work=El Pais|url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2018/10/22/inenglish/1540192063_943808.html}} because he had promised [[President of Andalusia]] [[Susana Díaz]] to help protect jobs in the shipyards of the [[Bay of Cádiz]], highly dependent on the €1.813 billion contract with Saudi Arabia to deliver five [[corvettes]].{{Cite journal|last1=Sanz|first1=Luis Ángel|last2=Cruz|first2=Marisa|last3=Villaverde|first3=Susana|date=24 October 2018|title=Pedro Sánchez evita una crisis con Arabia Saudí por el coste electoral en Andalucía|url=https://www.elmundo.es/espana/2018/10/24/5bcf6829e5fdeaf16b8b4644.html|journal=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]}}{{Cite journal|date=7 September 2018|title=El Gobierno garantiza el contrato de Arabia Saudí con Navantia, cuyos trabajadores han cortado la A-4|url=http://www.rtve.es/noticias/20180907/trabajadores-navantia-cortan-4-temor-se-cancele-contrato-arabia-saudi/1793562.shtml|publisher=[[RTVE]]}} In response to the killing of Saudi dissident journalist [[Jamal Khashoggi]] in October 2018, Sánchez defended the decision to continue arms sales to Saudi Arabia and insisted on his government's "responsibility" to protect jobs in the [[arms industry]].{{cite news|date=28 October 2018|title=How Saudis are getting away with Khashoggi murder|work=[[News.com.au]]|url=https://www.news.com.au/world/middle-east/how-saudis-are-getting-away-with-khashoggi-murder/news-story/4632ff5a196d9013a2b1b8e3e7139175}}{{cite news|date=24 October 2018|title=Need to keep jobs grounds for continuation of arms sales to Saudi Arabia, argues Spanish president|work=Catalan News|url=http://www.catalannews.com/politics/item/need-to-keep-jobs-grounds-for-continuation-of-arms-sales-to-saudi-arabia-argues-spanish-president}} === Plagiarism === In 2018 a newspaper revealed that his book ''La nueva diplomacia económica española'' includes the plagiarism of six other people's texts. The suspicion was extended to his doctoral thesis, whose authorship was questioned.{{cite news|date=14 September 2018|title=Un trabajo intrigante|newspaper=El País |url=https://elpais.com/politica/2018/09/13/actualidad/1536840669_711505.html|access-date=6 May 2019|language=es|last1=Domínguez |first1=Íñigo |last2=Pérez |first2=Fernando J. }} The authorship of his book ''Manual de resistencia'' is in doubt because Sánchez, who appears as the sole author, states in the prologue that "This book is the result of long hours of conversation with [[Irene Lozano]], writer, thinker, politician and friend. She gave a literary form to the recordings, giving me a decisive help".{{cite book|last=Sánchez Pérez-Castejón|first=Pedro|title=Manual de resistencia|publisher=Península|year=2019|isbn=9788499427959|location=Madrid|page=13}} The mentioned writer, for her part, affirmed that "I made the book, but the author is the [prime minister]".{{cite web|date=19 February 2019|title=Irene Lozano sobre el libro de Sánchez: "Yo hice el libro, pero el autor es el presidente"|url=https://www.elespanol.com/espana/politica/20190219/irene-lozano-libro-sanchez-hice-autor-presidente/377463387_0.html|work=El Español|language=es}} == Electoral history == {|
